headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you thought about our Small Group business, you should really think about it in 3 blocks, if you will. There's the 51 to 100 business that is not subject to ACA. Margin-wise, that business is fine, at target margins, maybe even a hair better. We also h
componenttext: If you thought about our Small Group business, you should really think about it in 3 blocks, if you will. There's the 51 to 100 business that is not subject to ACA. Margin-wise, that business is fine, at target margins, maybe even a hair better. We also have the 2 to 50, that is to keep what you have. That is not in the ACA yet. That business is performing fine. So the only one that is off is the Small Group ACA business, and that business is probably running a modest pretax loss for 2016. Let's say, low single digits is the way that, that looks right now. The pricing question is a difficult one to answer in the sense that if you're dealing with selection issues, as we saw this year, the traditional pricing level -- lever that works in stable environments doesn't always have the desired effect. So I would say, at a high level, the pricing environment has been fine, but I think the issues with the Small Group ACA block require things other than pricing in order to potentially improve the outcome there.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just comment that we continue to see a deterioration in the risk pool for Small Group ACA. And although there's been a lot of struggles in this segment, we are seeing sort of the better risk looking at alternatives. So we are offering alternat
componenttext: And I would just comment that we continue to see a deterioration in the risk pool for Small Group ACA. And although there's been a lot of struggles in this segment, we are seeing sort of the better risk looking at alternatives. So we are offering alternative product funds. We also are seeing that book move to PEOs, and the good news is we have products in both of those areas to offer those Small Group ACA clients.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Karen, any view on why the Small Group risk pool is getting worse? Obviously, we're not seeing the Individual pool getting any better, so we know that it's not that you're having the favorable Small Group risk sort of swap into Individual. So any sense on
componenttext: Karen, any view on why the Small Group risk pool is getting worse? Obviously, we're not seeing the Individual pool getting any better, so we know that it's not that you're having the favorable Small Group risk sort of swap into Individual. So any sense on why that pool is deteriorating as well.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is operating very similar to the Individual ACA book. And it is in certain geographies, as I've talked about before, so it's not widespread. So we're seeing it emerge, but I would say that we've got very good targeted strategies that really -- you have
componenttext: It is operating very similar to the Individual ACA book. And it is in certain geographies, as I've talked about before, so it's not widespread. So we're seeing it emerge, but I would say that we've got very good targeted strategies that really -- you have to really understand all the risk dynamics, and we've got very good targeted strategies to address that, including pricing.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Newshel with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Newshel with Evercore ISI.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to follow up on the changes you mentioned in the way you approach a Medicaid procurement. In your mind, is there anything about the capabilities of your Medicaid platform that need to be fixed or enhanced? Or is the issue more just about the way
componenttext: I'd like to follow up on the changes you mentioned in the way you approach a Medicaid procurement. In your mind, is there anything about the capabilities of your Medicaid platform that need to be fixed or enhanced? Or is the issue more just about the way you actually write the contract and the submission in terms of getting a good score?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're really confident in our capabilities, and our integrated care management model is stellar. We believe it is a very strong model. I think, as I mentioned, as evidenced by some of our recent wins. And really, I think it's a fundamental process of
componenttext: No, we're really confident in our capabilities, and our integrated care management model is stellar. We believe it is a very strong model. I think, as I mentioned, as evidenced by some of our recent wins. And really, I think it's a fundamental process of changing the way in which we go about procurement. And we've got leadership very focused on working of that activity.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, let me support that even more when you think about, we have consistently been able, once we have these contracts, to sort of deliver improved quality, lower costs, and for all of you, target margins. And I would just look at what we were abl
componenttext: Yes, Michael, let me support that even more when you think about, we have consistently been able, once we have these contracts, to sort of deliver improved quality, lower costs, and for all of you, target margins. And I would just look at what we were able to do in Kentucky in terms of turning that around. Karen mentioned sort of some independent scoring of our care model by CMS. So when we have this business, I think it's indisputable that we have the capabilities to create good outcomes. So going back to Karen's point, this is a front-end procurement issue that we need to focus on.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And were you able to make any of these exchanges for your rebid in Pennsylvania?
componenttext: And were you able to make any of these exchanges for your rebid in Pennsylvania?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we were.
componenttext: Yes, we were.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just hoping to get some additional clarification on the $350 million of losses in the Individual book. I'm assuming it's split between both the off- and the on-exchange, but can you give us a sense of how it's split between the 2? Is the majority, a vast
componenttext: Just hoping to get some additional clarification on the $350 million of losses in the Individual book. I'm assuming it's split between both the off- and the on-exchange, but can you give us a sense of how it's split between the 2? Is the majority, a vast majority of it in the on-exchange, which I think it is? But then, more importantly, when we look to next year in the residual off-exchange book, you think the losses there will get worse or will they go down?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. One is there is a substantial loss in that $350 million on both on- and off-exchange. Proportionate to the membership, it is a bit more disproportional to the off-exchange on a per member basis, but both sides of that equation are making up la
componenttext: Two things. One is there is a substantial loss in that $350 million on both on- and off-exchange. Proportionate to the membership, it is a bit more disproportional to the off-exchange on a per member basis, but both sides of that equation are making up large components of the $350 million loss. Obviously, it's our intent to decrease the loss on that off-exchange business. The variable on that, though, is still to be played out through sort of the enrollment process in terms of what levels of volume we get or don't get on that business.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We used 4 factors to try and size our participation for next year. One was the amount of capital at risk in any given market. We have seen in some states a fairly significant shift from '15 to '16 in the financial performance of those businesses. Secondly
componenttext: We used 4 factors to try and size our participation for next year. One was the amount of capital at risk in any given market. We have seen in some states a fairly significant shift from '15 to '16 in the financial performance of those businesses. Secondly, we used the competitive frame, how many people are in the market. When you're the last one left in the market, you get all the risk and there isn't any risk to share. The third was whether or not we could continue to offer broad enough product offering without putting that much capital at risk, including the size of a loss in any one given market. And the fourth was regulatory framework within the market itself.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dave Windley with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dave Windley with Jefferies.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the operating expense picture, can you comment perhaps on maybe the factor or factors that have been most contributory to your savings? Second part of that would be, to what extent has the operating expense margin benefited from a shift in mix toward G
componenttext: On the operating expense picture, can you comment perhaps on maybe the factor or factors that have been most contributory to your savings? Second part of that would be, to what extent has the operating expense margin benefited from a shift in mix toward Government business? And then, third, are there any perhaps major initiatives that are on hold per se pending the Humana deal?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first couple, then turn it to Mark. But you're right, Dave, we can follow up with the specifics. As we've grown Government, that has a lower expense ratio, so that's helped. But make no mistake, we have a pretty concerted effort to improve p
componenttext: I'll take the first couple, then turn it to Mark. But you're right, Dave, we can follow up with the specifics. As we've grown Government, that has a lower expense ratio, so that's helped. But make no mistake, we have a pretty concerted effort to improve productivity throughout the company. That's been in place for a couple of years now. It's, in some ways, still ramping up. But as I mentioned in our previous call, I think you're beginning to see the fruits of that initiative this year in terms of where we are on the maturities. So the kinds of things we're doing through that effort are not temporary holdbacks of spending. They are things that both improve the quality of the end product to the customer but also sort of make us more efficient. So when we grow, this is a high-fixed expense business, so we always get some form of leverage. That has helped. This productivity initiative has also contributed significantly to that as well.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think it's that productivity initiative that feeds into the integration discussion we're having with Humana. The work we're doing is value stream Six Sigma level work, where we're taking each business process and the employees in that process to eva
componenttext: And I think it's that productivity initiative that feeds into the integration discussion we're having with Humana. The work we're doing is value stream Six Sigma level work, where we're taking each business process and the employees in that process to evaluate and develop a better customer experience. And we've seen a lot of that happening in Medicare already, which is yielding a high outcome on our stars ratings. And we continue to move that across the business. We are not fully embedded. As it relates to the Humana transaction, there are a number of opportunities that we view as earlier wins for us in expanding to more markets. However, that is not putting our own expansion efforts on hold. We continue to do the work that we expected to do in anticipation of our plan as it was before we did the Humana transaction, and we are looking at some systems investments as opportunities with Humana, but you have a trade-off. We may get some benefits out of Humana acquisition in the way of technology investments, in the way of program investments, but we're also going to have make investments in the company, in Humana in fixing things like the large Commercial business, et cetera. So all of that trade-off is really a deployment of capital discussion, and quite frankly, in the end, we're continuing to move ahead with our plan as if the Humana acquisition didn't happen.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. If I could just clarify on the membership question. So for Karen, if I understand your response to an earlier question, the National Accounts is essentially a push in terms of high retention but, also limited activity in new sales, and then Group
componenttext: Got it. If I could just clarify on the membership question. So for Karen, if I understand your response to an earlier question, the National Accounts is essentially a push in terms of high retention but, also limited activity in new sales, and then Group MA is also a push good sales activity offsetting a conversion. Do I understand that correctly?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that you should see modest growth in Group Medicare, and then we'll have less attrition in National Accounts than we did last year.
componenttext: I would say that you should see modest growth in Group Medicare, and then we'll have less attrition in National Accounts than we did last year.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Lance Wilkes with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Lance Wilkes with Bernstein.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Could you just give an update on -- for prior-period development? How much of that was in the Government space, in Medicaid, specifically? And then, related to that, strategically, what's your appetite in the Medicaid space? And what sort of capabili
componenttext: Yes. Could you just give an update on -- for prior-period development? How much of that was in the Government space, in Medicaid, specifically? And then, related to that, strategically, what's your appetite in the Medicaid space? And what sort of capabilities would you be looking at if you were to ultimately do some strategic capital deployment there?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lance, we don't disclose specifically prior-period development and/or even by product. What I would tell you is that all 3 of our major product lines, Commercial, Medicare and Medicaid all experienced favorable development in the quarter, with that mainly
componenttext: Lance, we don't disclose specifically prior-period development and/or even by product. What I would tell you is that all 3 of our major product lines, Commercial, Medicare and Medicaid all experienced favorable development in the quarter, with that mainly being attributable to second quarter. Again, the Medicaid discussion is one that goes back to our prior discussion, which is from a core capability standpoint in terms of when we have these contracts. I think our track record is actually very good in terms of the results. So this continues to be about the procurement side of this, and we're certainly going to attack that organically, because we think it's something that we can and should be able to fix.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if you were looking at any of the capabilities on the LTC side or some of the PBMS [indiscernible] but any of those that you feel are lacking?
componenttext: Great. And if you were looking at any of the capabilities on the LTC side or some of the PBMS [indiscernible] but any of those that you feel are lacking?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, our LTSS performance, actually even in procurement, to some extent, but even the business we have is actually been very good. So not -- I probably would say not at this level of discussion. I couldn't think of anything there.
componenttext: Certainly, our LTSS performance, actually even in procurement, to some extent, but even the business we have is actually been very good. So not -- I probably would say not at this level of discussion. I couldn't think of anything there.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just echo Shawn's comments there. I think our underlying performance of our capability is strong in our Medicaid business.
componenttext: Yes, I would just echo Shawn's comments there. I think our underlying performance of our capability is strong in our Medicaid business.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Sorry about that earlier. I guess, 2 questions. First, it sounds like the Individual business has gotten worse, but you're exiting a lot of the market. Would you say that the deterioration is more skewed towards either the business you're staying i
componenttext: Great. Sorry about that earlier. I guess, 2 questions. First, it sounds like the Individual business has gotten worse, but you're exiting a lot of the market. Would you say that the deterioration is more skewed towards either the business you're staying in or the business that you're leaving?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is worse, and I would say that it's difficult to say whether off of 1 quarter, I wouldn't want to make a directional comment out of this. I think we still feel -- Mark described the framework before that we used to sort of assess this from a business p
componenttext: It is worse, and I would say that it's difficult to say whether off of 1 quarter, I wouldn't want to make a directional comment out of this. I think we still feel -- Mark described the framework before that we used to sort of assess this from a business perspective, and that framework is really more of an enterprise risk management framework than it was sort of a market-by-market seriatim buildup. So I think looking at it today, I think we still feel good about trying to stay in the box that we established for next year. Having said that, we really need to go through the enrollment process and see how each of these markets on- and off-exchange play out.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember, we're still working off a Wakely data, which is complete and has a lot of potential movement in it. So these are estimates still at this point in time.
componenttext: Remember, we're still working off a Wakely data, which is complete and has a lot of potential movement in it. So these are estimates still at this point in time.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you mentioned before that, obviously, you're not going to able to get rid of all the exchange losses, but if we said that you were going to exit, I guess, call it 70% of your revenue and let's assume that meant 70% of the losses on the exchanges.
componenttext: And then you mentioned before that, obviously, you're not going to able to get rid of all the exchange losses, but if we said that you were going to exit, I guess, call it 70% of your revenue and let's assume that meant 70% of the losses on the exchanges. Are you talking about the fact that you're going to keep their side of losses or that even on the 70% of losses, those don't go all away because of fixed costs? And how do we -- if it's the latter, how do we think about retaining of the fixed cost infrastructure?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Until we see the enrollment, we're not really going to get too far with assessing what the loss will be. We made estimates off of the current book of business, which, by the way, turned over almost 55% this last year. We had a certain frame of competitors
componenttext: Until we see the enrollment, we're not really going to get too far with assessing what the loss will be. We made estimates off of the current book of business, which, by the way, turned over almost 55% this last year. We had a certain frame of competitors in each market, which has already changed. More people have left the exchanges since we have. And so until we get a look at what the membership looks like, we're not going to really be able to nail the number with any degree of certainty. We certainly did it to reduce fairly dramatically the amount of capital we had at risk and the amount of losses we would sustain. Negative returns on invested capital are not sustainable over the long term, and so we try to reduce both.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, then maybe just last question. Throughout the year, it sounds like the Government business has made up for the fact that there's some pressure on the ACA-compliant businesses throughout the year. You still -- although characterize both Medicaid and
componenttext: Okay, then maybe just last question. Throughout the year, it sounds like the Government business has made up for the fact that there's some pressure on the ACA-compliant businesses throughout the year. You still -- although characterize both Medicaid and Medicare as kind of in your target margin ranges, would it be fair to say they're kind of now at the higher end of that range? I guess trying to think about, directionally, would we expect maybe reversion of the Government book next year? Or are we kind of where you would expect?

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at how we've deployed the health insurance fee change, we have a number of markets that are at the MLR limit. So we were able to give those more in benefits and to preserve margins in the business. But there are only so far you can go, s
componenttext: Well, if you look at how we've deployed the health insurance fee change, we have a number of markets that are at the MLR limit. So we were able to give those more in benefits and to preserve margins in the business. But there are only so far you can go, so that should help our growth come January 1. There are other markets where we were not necessarily performing up to oil and we had to correct those. But all in all, what we tried to do was make sure that we weren't having to pay rebates that we made sure that we gave those back in benefits to seniors. We preserved margins and we kept as many 0 premium plans as possible.

headline: Aetna Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. A transcript of the prepared portion of this call will be posted shortly on Investor Information section of aetna.com, where you'll also find a copy of our updated guidance summary containing details of our guidance metrics, including th
componenttext: Thank you, Kevin. A transcript of the prepared portion of this call will be posted shortly on Investor Information section of aetna.com, where you'll also find a copy of our updated guidance summary containing details of our guidance metrics, including those that were unchanged or not discussed on this call. If you have any questions about matters discuss this morning, please feel free to call me in the Investor Relations office. Thank you for joining us this morning.
